Abstract

A multi-hop synchronous wirelss network is said to be unknown if the nodes have no knowledge of the topology. A basic task in wireless network is that of broadcasting a message (created by a fixed source node) to all nodes of the network. Typical operations in real-life wireless networks is the multi-broadcast that consists in performing a set of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r independent broadcasts. The study of broadcast operations on unknown wireless network is started by the seminal paper of Bar-Yehuda et alÂ [BGI87] and has been the subject of several recent works.

In this paper, we study the completion and the termination time of distributed protocols for both the (single) broadcast and the multi-broadcast operations on unknown networks as functions of the number of nodes nğ‘›nitalic_n, the maximum eccentricity Dğ·Ditalic_D, the maximum in-degree Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, and the congestion cğ‘citalic_c of the networks. We establish new connections between these operations and some combinatorial concepts, such as selective families, strongly-selective families (also known as superimposed codes), and pairwise rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-different families. Such connections, combined with a set of new lower and upper bounds on the size of the above families, allow us to derive new lower bounds and new distributed protocols for the broadcast and multi-broadcast operations.

In particular, our upper bounds are almost tight and improve exponentially over the previous bounds when Dğ·Ditalic_D and Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” are polylogarithmic in nğ‘›nitalic_n. Network topologies having â€œsmallâ€ eccentricity and â€œsmallâ€ degree (such as bounded-degree expanders) are often used in practice to achieve efficient communication.

1 Introduction

1.1 Wireless networks

Static ad-hoc wireless networks (in short, radio networks) have been the subject of several works in recent years due to their potential applications in scenarios such as battlefields, emergency disaster relief, and in any situation in which it is very difficult (or impossible) to provide the necessary infrastructure [R96, WNE00]. As in other network models, a challenging task is to enable fast communication.

A radio network is a set of radio stations that are able to communicate by transmitting and receiving radio signals. A transmission range is assigned to each station sğ‘ sitalic_s and any other station within this range can directly (i.e. by one hop) receive messages from sğ‘ sitalic_s. Communication between two stations that are not within their respective ranges can be achieved by multi-hop transmissions. A useful (and sometimes unavoidable) paradigm of radio communication is the structuring of communication into synchronous time-slots. This paradigm is commonly adopted in the practical design of protocols and hence the use of the paradigm in theoretical analysis is well motivated [BGI87, G85, R72].

A radio network can be modeled as a directed graph where an edge (u,v)ğ‘¢ğ‘£(u,v)( italic_u , italic_v ) exists if and only if uğ‘¢uitalic_u can communicate with vğ‘£vitalic_v in one hop. The nodes of a radio network are processing units, each of which is able to perform local computations. It is also assumed that every node can perform any local computation required for deciding the next send/receive operation during the current time-slot. In every time-slot, each node can be active or non active. When active, it can decide to be either transmitter or receiver: in the former case the node transmits a message along all of its outgoing edges while, in the latter case, it tries to recover messages from all its incoming edges. When it is not active, it does not perform any kind of operation. The fundamental feature here is that a node vğ‘£vitalic_v can recover a message from one of its incoming edges if and only if this edge is the only one bringing in a message. If two or more neighbors of a node are transmitting at the same time-slot then a collision occurs. Nodes do not distinguish between the background noise and the interference noise (i.e., we are in the case of absence of collision detection [PL95, BGI87]). A radio network is said to be unknown when every node knows nothing about the network but its own labelÂ [BGI87, CGGPR00, CGOR00, CGR00]. Informally speaking, unknown radio networks, with absence of collision detection, model communication networks with multi-access channels in which the assumptions on the processorsâ€™ knowledge and on the channel are minimal. In fact, in several applications, the network topology is unstable or dynamic and it is difficult to distinguish the presence of a collision from the background noise of the channel. Another important motivation in studying unknown networks comes from its strong connection with the fault-tolerance issue [PR97, KKP98, KM98, CMS01c]. Unknown networks can also be seen as â€œknownâ€ networks (i.e. networks in which nodes have the knowledge of the entire initial topology) with unknown permanent faults. A node (or an edge) is said to suffer a permanent fault if it is never active during the entire execution of the protocol [KKP98, CMS01c]. It is easy to show that a broadcast protocol for unknown fault-free networks is also an (unknown permanent-)fault tolerant protocol for general (known) networks and viceversa. So, the results obtained in the unknown model immediately apply to the permanent-fault tolerance issue.

One of the fundamental tasks in network communication is the broadcast operation. It consists in transmitting a message from one source node to all the nodes.

According to the network model described above, the communication protocol operates in time-slots: at every time-slot, each active node decides to either transmit or receive, or turn into the non active state. Two kinds of broadcast protocols have been considered in the literature [BGI87, BD97, CGGPR00, CGOR00]: spontaneous protocols, in which the starting time-slot is known to all the nodes and, thus, every node can transmit even if it has not received any message in previous time-slots; non spontaneous protocols in which a node (which is not the source) may act as a transmitter in a time-slot only if it has received a message in some previous time-slots (while the source starts at time-slot 0). A deterministic (randomized) broadcast protocol is said to have completed broadcasting when all nodes, reachable from the source, have received (with high probability111A formal definition of completion time for randomized protocols will be given later.) the source message. Notice that when this happens, the nodes not necessarily stop to run the protocol since they might not know that the operation is completed. We also say that a broadcast protocol terminates in time tğ‘¡titalic_t if, after the time-slot tğ‘¡titalic_t, all the nodes are in the non active state (i.e. when all nodes stop to run the protocol).

The completion and termination time of Deterministic (Randomized) Broadcast protocols, in short DB (RB) protocols, will be analysed as functions of the following parameters of the network: the number nğ‘›nitalic_n of nodes, the maximum in-degree Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, and the maximum eccentricity Dğ·Ditalic_D over all possible source nodes. Given a source node sğ‘ sitalic_s, the eccentricity of sğ‘ sitalic_s is the largest distance between sğ‘ sitalic_s and any node of the network. Observe that the maximum eccentricity equals the diameter in the case of symmetric networks.

A typical task in real-life radio networks is that of performing a set of simultaneous and independent broadcast operations: a multi-broadcast operation is to perform râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1italic_r â‰¥ 1 broadcasts (from an arbitrary multiset of source nodes). The completion time of a Deterministic (Randomized) multi-Broadcast protocol, in short multi-DB (multi-RB) protocols, is defined as follows. A multi-DB (multi-RB) protocol on a radio network has completion time tğ‘¡titalic_t if, (with high probability) every broadcast message is received by all the nodes reachable from the source of the message within the first tğ‘¡titalic_t time-slots. The termination time of a multi-DB (multi-RB) protocol is defined as for DB protocols.

As for the channel bandwidth, we distinguish two models. In the Unbounded-Bandwidth (in short UB) model [CGR00], a node can send/receive messages of unbounded size (so, a node can send an arbitrary large subset of the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r messages in one time-slot). In the Bounded-Bandwidth (in short BB) model [BII93], every node can send messages of size at most Oâ¢(logâ¡n+logâ¡r)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘ŸO(\log n+\log r)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n + roman_log italic_r ) in one time-slot. In this model, the completion time of the protocols also depends on the congestion (denoted as cğ‘citalic_c) which is defined as the maximum number of broadcast messages that a node has to receive (where the maximum is computed over all possible nodes).

1.2 Previous results

On the other hand, their randomized protocol does not terminate when no upper bound on nğ‘›nitalic_n is known. It thus turns out that all previous deterministic upper bounds are superlinear (in nğ‘›nitalic_n) independently of the parameters Dğ·Ditalic_D and Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” of the network. In several wireless network applications, network topologies with â€œsmallâ€ diameter and â€œsmallâ€ degree are typically adopted in order to achieve fast and reliable communication [AS92, Lei91, KR96]. By comparing the above upper bounds with our deterministic lower bound, we have that our multi-DB protocols turn out to be â€œalmostâ€ optimal (i.e., only a polylogarithmic factor away from the lower bound) when Î”=Oâ¢(polyâ¢logâ¡n)Î”ğ‘‚polyğ‘›\Delta=O({\rm poly}\log n)roman_Î” = italic_O ( roman_poly roman_log italic_n ). We also emphasize that, for Î”=Oâ¢(1)Î”ğ‘‚1\Delta=O(1)roman_Î” = italic_O ( 1 ), our deterministic upper bound is almost equivalent to the Oâ¢((D+r)â¢logâ¡Î”â¢logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ·ğ‘ŸÎ”ğ‘›O((D+r)\log\Delta\log n)italic_O ( ( italic_D + italic_r ) roman_log roman_Î” roman_log italic_n ) randomized upper boundÂ [BII93] in which it is even assumed that the network is symmetric and the nodes know their respective neighborhood.

As for the UB model, since arbitrary large concatenation of the messages inside a node can be sent along the outgoing edges, we can use a simpler version of our multi-DB protocols. In this version, the local scheduling is not required and, thus, we get an Oâ¢(Dâ¢Î”2â¢log2+Î±â¡n)ğ‘‚ğ·superscriptÎ”2superscript2ğ›¼ğ‘›O(D\Delta^{2}\log^{2+\alpha}n)italic_O ( italic_D roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 + italic_Î± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) upper bound.

1.4 Organization of the paper

Section 2 provides an overview of the connections between the issue of radio broadcasting and some combinatorial concepts and results. In Section 3, the proofs of such combinatorial results are given. Section 4 describes the results on the broadcast operation. In Section 5, the results on the multi-broadcast operation are presented. Finally, Section 6 discusses the obtained results and proposes some open problems.

2 Adopted techniques and some new combinatorial results: an overview

The proofs of our upper and lower bounds exploit some new combinatorial results that we believe to have a per se interest. In this section, we provide a description of such results and we outline their connection with broadcast and multi-broadcast operations.

In [CGGPR00], Chlebus et al introduced the use of selective families in designing DB protocols in unknown networks. In what follows, the set {1,â€¦,n}1â€¦ğ‘›\{1,\ldots,n\}{ 1 , â€¦ , italic_n } is denoted as [n]delimited-[]ğ‘›[n][ italic_n ].

Definition 2.1

Let nğ‘›nitalic_n and kğ‘˜kitalic_k be any integers with kâ‰¤nğ‘˜ğ‘›k\leq nitalic_k â‰¤ italic_n. A family â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F of subsets of [n]delimited-[]ğ‘›[n][ italic_n ] is (n,k)ğ‘›ğ‘˜(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-selective if, for every non empty subset Zğ‘Zitalic_Z of [n]delimited-[]ğ‘›[n][ italic_n ] such that |Z|â‰¤kğ‘ğ‘˜|Z|\leq k| italic_Z | â‰¤ italic_k, there is a set Fğ¹Fitalic_F in â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F such that |Zâˆ©F|=1ğ‘ğ¹1|Z\cap F|=1| italic_Z âˆ© italic_F | = 1.

In fact, selective families can be used to design oblivious DB protocols. A protocol is oblivious when its actions can be scheduled in advance. Let â„±={F1,â€¦,Fm}â„±subscriptğ¹1â€¦subscriptğ¹ğ‘š{\cal F}=\{F_{1},\ldots,F_{m}\}caligraphic_F = { italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be an (n,Î”)ğ‘›Î”(n,\Delta)( italic_n , roman_Î” )-selective family. Then, it is easy to define an oblivious DB protocol on a network of nğ‘›nitalic_n nodes and maximum in-degree Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” (this protocol has been introduced in [CGGPR00, CGOR00]).

A node uğ‘¢uitalic_u transmits at time-slot tâ‰¤mğ‘¡ğ‘št\leq mitalic_t â‰¤ italic_m iff it has received the source message (i.e. it is informed) and uâˆˆFtğ‘¢subscriptğ¹ğ‘¡u\in F_{t}italic_u âˆˆ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

During the execution of these mğ‘šmitalic_m time-slots, thanks to the selective property of â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F, for each set of dâ‰¤Î”ğ‘‘Î”d\leq\Deltaitalic_d â‰¤ roman_Î” nodes, there is at least one time-slot in which only one of the nodes of the set can transmit. This guarantees that at least one non informed node gets informed. By iterating this process nğ‘›nitalic_n times, the broadcast is completed. Thus the completion time of such DB protocol is nâ¢|â„±|ğ‘›â„±n|{\cal F}|italic_n | caligraphic_F |.

We prove that there exist (n,k)ğ‘›ğ‘˜(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-selective families of size Oâ¢(kâ¢logâ¡(n/k))ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(k\log(n/k))italic_O ( italic_k roman_log ( italic_n / italic_k ) ). We also prove that this upper bound is optimal, that is, any (n,k)ğ‘›ğ‘˜(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-selective family has size Î©â¢(kâ¢logâ¡(n/k))Î©ğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘˜\Omega(k\log(n/k))roman_Î© ( italic_k roman_log ( italic_n / italic_k ) ). On one hand, such small selective families are combined with a new broadcast technique in order to obtain our DB protocols. On the other hand, the lower bound on the size of selective families allows us to obtain lower bounds on the completion time of DB protocols.

In designing multi-DB protocols, we introduce families of sets having a stronger selective property.

Since a lower bound on the size of strongly-selective families determines a lower bound on the completion time of our multi-broadcast technique, we have also investigated this combinatorial aspect. This implies that there are no significantly smaller strongly-selective families than those adopted by our protocols.

As in the case of selective families, we tried to exploit strongly-selective families to obtain good lower bounds on the completion time of multi-DB protocols. But we could not obtain anything better than the lower bound for single broadcast.

In the BB model, besides the interference problems, the bound on the channel bandwidth yields further delays due to the congestion inside the nodes of the network. We exploit this aspect to obtain a non trivial lower bound. Consider the following situation that can happen during the execution of a multi-broadcast protocol. There are nğ‘›nitalic_n nodes each of them having rğ‘Ÿritalic_r messages. They are not connected each other, and exactly two of them are the only in-neighbours of another node uğ‘¢uitalic_u. Thus, all the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r messages can be received by uğ‘¢uitalic_u only if, for every pair of nodes and for each message, there is a time-slot in which exactly one of the nodes of the pair transmits that message and the other does not transmit anything. This suggests to introduce the following notion.

Definition 2.3

Two sequences xâ†’normal-â†’ğ‘¥\vec{x}overâ†’ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG and yâ†’normal-â†’ğ‘¦\vec{y}overâ†’ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG of equal length over the alphabet {0}âˆª[r]0delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿ\{0\}\cup[r]{ 0 } âˆª [ italic_r ] are rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-different if for any zâˆˆ[r]ğ‘§delimited-[]ğ‘Ÿz\in[r]italic_z âˆˆ [ italic_r ] there is a coordinate iğ‘–iitalic_i for which {xi,yi}={z,0}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘§0\{x_{i},y_{i}\}=\{z,0\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = { italic_z , 0 }.

From the situation described above, we will show that a protocol which performs any multi-broadcast operation on unknown networks within tğ‘¡titalic_t time-slots must yield a set of nğ‘›nitalic_n pairwise rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-different sequences of length not greater than tğ‘¡titalic_t. By combining this connection with a new lower bound on the length of such sequences, i.e. Î©â¢((r/logâ¡r)â¢logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›\Omega((r/\log r)\log n)roman_Î© ( ( italic_r / roman_log italic_r ) roman_log italic_n ), we derive the lower bounds for the multi-broadcast operation on the BB model.

4 Broadcast operations

4.1 The lower bounds

In this section, we show the existence of an infinite family of directed graphs that force any DB protocol to perform, in the worst-case, Î©â¢(nâ¢logâ¡D)Î©ğ‘›ğ·\Omega(n\log D)roman_Î© ( italic_n roman_log italic_D ) time-slots before completing a broadcast. Then, we provide a simple variant of this family of graphs yielding a lower bound that also depends on Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”. Our lower bound holds for the UB model (and, thus, for the BB model too). We first formalize the notion of DB protocol according to [BGI87].

Definition 4.1

A Deterministic distributed Broadcast DB protocol Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is a protocol that works in time-slots (numbered 0,1,â€¦01normal-â€¦0,1,\ldots0 , 1 , â€¦) according to the following rules.

  1. 1.

    In the initial time-slot a specified node (i.e. the source) transmits a message (called the source message).

  2. 2.

    In each time-slot, each node either acts as transmitter or as receiver or is non active.

  3. 3.

    A node receives a message in a time-slot if and only if it acts as receiver and exactly one of its iâ¢nğ‘–ğ‘›initalic_i italic_n-neighbors acts as transmitter in that time-slot.

  4. 4.

    The action of a node in a specific time-slot is a function of its own label, the number of the current time-slot tğ‘¡titalic_t, and the messages received during the previous time-slots.

4.2 The upper bounds

This section provides a DB protocol for unknown networks. For case of exposition, we first describe the protocol that assume the knowledge of nğ‘›nitalic_n and Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”. Then, we show how to extend the same technique to the cases in which Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” and nğ‘›nitalic_n are not known by the nodes.

The following protocol assumes the knowledge of Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” and nğ‘›nitalic_n.

Description of Protocol broad-aâ¢(n,Î”)broad-ağ‘›normal-Î”\mbox{\sc broad-a}(n,\Delta)broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Î” ). The protocol uses an (n,Î”)ğ‘›Î”(n,\Delta)( italic_n , roman_Î” )-selective family â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F. It starts by setting all the nodes to the active state, and by let sğ‘ sitalic_s transmit the source message. After the first time-slot, it turns sğ‘ sitalic_s to the non active state. Then, it performs a sequence of consecutive identical phases. Let us fix an arbitrary ordering for the sets of â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F; at time-slot jğ‘—jitalic_j of phase iğ‘–iitalic_i, each node vğ‘£vitalic_v acts according to the following rule: vğ‘£vitalic_v transmits the source message along its outgoing edges if and only if

  • 1)

    the label of vğ‘£vitalic_v belongs to the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th set of â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F, and

  • 2)

    vğ‘£vitalic_v has received the source message for the first time during the phase iâˆ’1ğ‘–1i-1italic_i - 1.

After the phase in which a node vğ‘£vitalic_v acts as a transmitter, it turns to the non active state (so, this is a first change w.r.t. the straightforward protocol described in SectionÂ 2). The active nodes that, at at time-slot jğ‘—jitalic_j of any phase, have a state not satisfying Conditions (1)1(1)( 1 ) and (2)2(2)( 2 ) act as receivers. Observe that Condition (2)2(2)( 2 ) is the key difference between our technique and the straightforward one. As we will see in the analysis of the protocol, this difference will play a crucial role in order to achieve an upper bound not containing the linear factor nğ‘›nitalic_n.

Theorem 4.3

Protocol broad-aâ¢(n,Î”)broad-ağ‘›normal-Î”\mbox{\sc broad-a}(n,\Delta)broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Î” ) completes broadcasting and terminates in Oâ¢(Dâ¢Î”â¢logâ¡(n/Î”))ğ‘‚ğ·normal-Î”ğ‘›normal-Î”O(D\Delta\log(n/\Delta))italic_O ( italic_D roman_Î” roman_log ( italic_n / roman_Î” ) ) time-slots on any nğ‘›nitalic_n-node graph of maximum eccentricity Dğ·Ditalic_D and maximum in-degree Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”.

Proof. Since, TheoremÂ 3.1 implies that |â„±|=Oâ¢(Dâ¢Î”â¢logâ¡(n/Î”))â„±ğ‘‚ğ·Î”ğ‘›Î”|{\cal F}|=O(D\Delta\log(n/\Delta))| caligraphic_F | = italic_O ( italic_D roman_Î” roman_log ( italic_n / roman_Î” ) ), the thesis is an easy consequence of the following claim.

Claim. A node vğ‘£vitalic_v receives (for the first time) the source message at phase iğ‘–iitalic_i of protocol broad-aâ¢(n,Î”)broad-ağ‘›Î”\mbox{\sc broad-a}(n,\Delta)broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Î” ) if and only if vğ‘£vitalic_v is at distance i+1ğ‘–1i+1italic_i + 1 from the source sğ‘ sitalic_s.
Proof. The proof is by induction on iğ‘–iitalic_i. (â‡â‡\Leftarrowâ‡). For i=0ğ‘–0i=0italic_i = 0 the Claim is obvious. We thus assume that all nodes at distance iğ‘–iitalic_i have received the source message during phase iâˆ’1ğ‘–1i-1italic_i - 1. Let us consider a node vğ‘£vitalic_v at distance i+1ğ‘–1i+1italic_i + 1 during phase iğ‘–iitalic_i. This node has at least one informed in-neighbor at distance iğ‘–iitalic_i. According to the protocol, only the neighbors of vğ‘£vitalic_v informed in phase iâˆ’1ğ‘–1i-1italic_i - 1 will act as transmitters in phase iğ‘–iitalic_i. Then, from the (n,Î”)ğ‘›Î”(n,\Delta)( italic_n , roman_Î” )-selectivity of â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F, there will be a step of phase iğ‘–iitalic_i, in which only one of these informed in-neighbors will transmit to vğ‘£vitalic_v. (â‡’â‡’\Rightarrowâ‡’). If vğ‘£vitalic_v is not at distance i+1ğ‘–1i+1italic_i + 1 from sğ‘ sitalic_s, then two cases may arise. If vğ‘£vitalic_v is at distance less than i+1ğ‘–1i+1italic_i + 1 then, by the inductive hypothesis, vğ‘£vitalic_v has been informed before phase iğ‘–iitalic_i. Otherwise, vğ‘£vitalic_v is at distance greater than i+1ğ‘–1i+1italic_i + 1, so none of its in-neighbors has been informed before phase iğ‘–iitalic_i.

â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

5 Multi-Broadcast: The BB model

We first need to extend Definition 4.1 to multi-broadcast operations. We assume here that each message has an header containing a unique ID number so that two messages have different ID numbers.

Definition 5.1

A multi-DB (multi-RB) protocol Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is a protocol that, given a graph GğºGitalic_G and a set of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r broadcast operations on it (in short, an rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-broadcast operation, râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1italic_r â‰¥ 1), works in time-slots (numbered 0,1,â€¦01normal-â€¦0,1,\ldots0 , 1 , â€¦) according to the following rules.

  1. 1.

    In every time-slot, each node either acts as transmitter or as receiver. When transmitting, the node sends one message.

  2. 2.

    All the nodes share the same message-recovering function â„›â„›{\cal R}caligraphic_R that takes any message mğ‘šmitalic_m as input and, if any, returns the (unique) broadcast message contained in mğ‘šmitalic_m.

  3. 3.

    A node receives a message in a time-slot if and only if it acts as receiver and exactly one of its iâ¢nğ‘–ğ‘›initalic_i italic_n-neighbors acts as transmitter in that time-slot.

  4. 4.

    The actions of a node in a specific time-slot are function of its own label, the number of the current time-slot tğ‘¡titalic_t, and the messages received during the previous time-slots (for multi-RB protocols, the actions also depend on the output of a random bit generators).

5.1 The lower bound for deterministic protocols

The next theorem provides a lower bound which is a function of the congestion cğ‘citalic_c and nğ‘›nitalic_n.

5.2 Lower bound for randomized protocols

Any worst-case time bound of a randomized protocol can be considered reliable if it happens within a high probability on every possible instance. This concept is widely adopted in the field of randomized algorithmsÂ [MR95], and it can be easily adapted to the case of multi-broadcast operations on unknown networks.

Definition 5.2

The protocol multi-bb-broad-aâ¢(n,Î”)multi-bb-broad-ağ‘›Î”\mbox{\sc multi-bb-broad-a}(n,\Delta)multi-bb-broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Î” ) uses an (n,Î”+1)ğ‘›Î”1(n,\Delta+1)( italic_n , roman_Î” + 1 )-strongly-selective family â„±={F1,F2,â€¦â¢F|â„±|}â„±subscriptğ¹1subscriptğ¹2â€¦subscriptğ¹â„±{\cal F}=\{F_{1},F_{2},\ldots F_{|{\cal F}|}\}caligraphic_F = { italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F | end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. At the very beginning, the priority queues of the source nodes contain their broadcast messages, the other priority queues are empty. At the beginning of each phase, every node vğ‘£vitalic_v with a non empty priority extracts from the queue the message mvsubscriptğ‘šğ‘£m_{v}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of highest priority. At the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th time-slot of the phase, node vğ‘£vitalic_v acts according to the following rules.

- If the label of vğ‘£vitalic_v belongs to Fjsubscriptğ¹ğ‘—F_{j}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and mvsubscriptğ‘šğ‘£m_{v}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exists then vğ‘£vitalic_v transmits mvsubscriptğ‘šğ‘£m_{v}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
- In all the other cases, vğ‘£vitalic_v acts as a receiver. If vğ‘£vitalic_v receives a message that vğ‘£vitalic_v has never received before, the message is enqueued, otherwise, the message is discarded.

Theorem 5.5

Protocol multi-bb-broad-aâ¢(n,Î”)multi-bb-broad-ağ‘›normal-Î”\mbox{\sc multi-bb-broad-a}(n,\Delta)multi-bb-broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Î” ) completes any rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-broadcast operation within Oâ¢((D+c)â¢minâ¡{n,Î”2â¢logâ¡n})ğ‘‚ğ·ğ‘ğ‘›superscriptnormal-Î”2ğ‘›O((D+c)\min\{n,\Delta^{2}\log n\})italic_O ( ( italic_D + italic_c ) roman_min { italic_n , roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n } ) time-slots on any nğ‘›nitalic_n-node graph of maximum eccentricity Dğ·Ditalic_D, maximum in-degree Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, and congestion cğ‘citalic_c.

Proof. Firstly, we prove the following

Claim 1â€ƒIf a node vğ‘£vitalic_v transmits a message during a phase tğ‘¡titalic_t then all the out-neighbours of vğ‘£vitalic_v receive the message by the end of phase tğ‘¡titalic_t.

Proof. In fact, let uğ‘¢uitalic_u be any out-neighbour of vğ‘£vitalic_v. By virtue of the (n,Î”+1)ğ‘›Î”1(n,\Delta+1)( italic_n , roman_Î” + 1 )-strongly selectivity of â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F, there is a time-slot of phase tğ‘¡titalic_t in which uğ‘¢uitalic_u acts as a receiver and vğ‘£vitalic_v is the only node, among the in-neighbors of uğ‘¢uitalic_u (notice that these are at most Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”), that transmits. Hence, in that time-slot, uğ‘¢uitalic_u receives the message of vğ‘£vitalic_v.

Now, we can show that all messages reach their destinations.


Claim 2â€ƒAfter a finite number of phases, any message mğ‘šmitalic_m is received by all the nodes that are reachable from the source of mğ‘šmitalic_m.

Proof. The proof is by induction on the distance â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ from the source. For â„“=0â„“0\ell=0roman_â„“ = 0 the claim is obvious. Let uğ‘¢uitalic_u be a node at distance â„“+1â„“1\ell+1roman_â„“ + 1 from the source. Consider an in-neighbour vğ‘£vitalic_v of uğ‘¢uitalic_u at distance â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“. From the inductive hypothesis, node vğ‘£vitalic_v receives the message mğ‘šmitalic_m. The first time this happens, mğ‘šmitalic_m is enqueued in the priority queue of vğ‘£vitalic_v. According to the protocol, at the beginning of each phase, node vğ‘£vitalic_v extracts the message of highest priority and transmits it. Since there are less than rğ‘Ÿritalic_r messages of priority higher than that of mğ‘šmitalic_m and any message is enqueued at most once, it follows that vğ‘£vitalic_v extracts and transmits mğ‘šmitalic_m within at most rğ‘Ÿritalic_r phases. Thus, from ClaimÂ 1 node uğ‘¢uitalic_u receives the message mğ‘šmitalic_m.

The last step consists of showing that the messages cannot be delayed too much.

6 Conclusions and open problems

The main contribution of this paper is that of providing explicit and strong connections between a set of old and new combinatorial tools and the issue of broadcast operations in radio networks of unknown topology. Thanks to such connections, we have obtained new lower and upper bounds on the completion time of this important operation. We believe that the concept of selectivity and that of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-different sequences can have further applications to other distributed models in which the local knowledge is extremely low. Some evidence of our opinion is also given by some previous results [Lin92] in which strongly-selective families have been used for the distributed coloring problem in unknown graphs.

As for specific research directions, the following ones appear to be the most relevant.

The upper bounds for the DB protocols are not efficiently constructible since the corresponding â€œsmallâ€ selective families have been derived by using probabilistic arguments: it would thus be important to design an efficient deterministic algorithm that constructs such families.

The lower bounds for multi-DB (and multi-RB) protocols are consequences of the combinatorial lower bound Î©â¢(rlogâ¡râ¢logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›\Omega(\frac{r}{\log r}\log n)roman_Î© ( divide start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_r end_ARG roman_log italic_n ) on the length of nğ‘›nitalic_n pairwise rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-different sequences given in TheoremÂ 3.6. We do not know whether the latter is tight. As far as we know, the best upper bound is Oâ¢(râ¢logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘Ÿğ‘›O(r\log n)italic_O ( italic_r roman_log italic_n ). The deterministic upper bounds in TheoremÂ 5.5 almost match the lower bound in TheoremÂ 5.2, when Î”=Oâ¢(polyâ¢logâ¡n)Î”ğ‘‚polyğ‘›\Delta=O({\rm poly}\log n)roman_Î” = italic_O ( roman_poly roman_log italic_n ). An interesting future research goal is that of reducing the gap between upper and lower bounds for larger Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”. To this aim, we believe that a generalization of the Î©â¢(rlogâ¡râ¢logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›\Omega(\frac{r}{\log r}\log n)roman_Î© ( divide start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_r end_ARG roman_log italic_n ) lower bound to dğ‘‘ditalic_d-wise rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-different sequences could give a stronger lower bound that also depends on Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”.

A further research direction is that of using the same combinatorial tools to investigate the issue of dynamical-fault tolerance in radio networks. Dynamical edge and node faults may happen at any instant, even during the execution of a protocol. Some results on this direction have been recently obtained in [CMS01c].
